1.heading: Hat Check Counters.
1.title: "The Wig"
1.author: Reir Mik.
notes: Ferd'nand buys a wig, then checks it at the hat check counter on his way into a dinner.
Silent Ferdinand strip, from Diario las Americas (Miami), Feb. 3, 2000.

2.heading: Hat Dance.
2.title: The Blank in the Comics strip collection includes a file of one or more daily comic strips related to this keyword or topic. Call no.: PN6726 f.B55

3.heading: Hat Dance.
3.title: "Especially When That Gato is Wearing the Hat!"
3.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Speedy enjoys the Mexican hat dance; Sylvester is overwhelmed.

4.title: "The Hat on a Stick Gag"
4.author: by Art Gates
4.appears_in: 1 p. in The Human Torch, no. 8 (Summer 1942).
notes: Summary: "After trailing a crook, Swoopy and Windy find themselves captured rather than being the capturers!"

5.heading: "Hat on Hand"* / Desclozeaux. p. 38 in Evergreen Review, no.
5.author: [No author]
notes: Sequence of 6 drawings in which a man pushes a woman into the water, and when her hand reaches up for help, puts his hat over it.

6.heading: Hat Racks.
6.title: "He Has an Itchy Back"
6.author: Frank Johnson.
notes: Summary: Rex has borrowed the hat rack.

7.heading: Hat Racks.
7.title: "Slight Hang-Up"
7.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Plushbottom's been working a double shift, and comes home so tired he hangs his stuff on Emmy instead of on the hat rack.

8.heading: Hat Racks.
8.title: "Watch Your Hat and Coat"
8.author: Carl Anderson.
notes: Summary: Henry is concerned when he sees the sign in a restaurant, so he ties his companion's hat to the hat rack with string.

9.heading: Hat Racks.
9.title: "You Better Take The Dog Out Before He Has An Accident!"
9.author: Dik Browne.
notes: Summary: Sure enough, Snert knocks over the hat rack and breaks a vase.

10.title: "Hat Shopping"
10.author: Stan & Dan
10.appears_in: 1/2 p. in My Girl Pearl, no. 5 (July 1957)
notes: Eighth story.
Begins: I'd like to see some hats! Certainly, Madam... I. Lee, Stan. II. De Carlo, Dan. k. Shopping. Call no.: PN6728.2.M3M86no.5

notes: "With the Hat Sisters!"
Collection of The Mostly Unfabulous Social Life of Ethan Green.

20.heading: Hatcheries.
20.title: "I'm Playing Fish Hatchery"

notes: Summary: Garfield has 119 sardines in his mouth.

21.heading: Hatcheries.
21.title: "State Trout Hatchery"
21.author: Hanan.
notes: Summary: Louie's fish are small, but he buys a big fish from a boy, but then a game warden sees him by the hatchery sign.
Strip without words.

22.heading: Hatches.
22.title: "Don't Be Stupid, Open It!"
22.author: Falk & Barry.
notes: Summary: Two soldiers hear a tapping behind the hatch, and debate opening it.

23.heading: Hatches.
23.title: "Resort to Strategy"
23.author: by Phil Nowlan and Dick Calkins.
notes: Summary: Kane has Huer trapped in the control room, so Buck and Wilma go out the stern hatch to tackle him from behind.

24.heading: Hatches.
24.title: "Your Hatch Was Unlocked!"
24.author: Batiuk & Ayers.
notes: Summary: The kid gets into the car and unlocks the door, after Ed and the police couldn't do it.

25.title: "A Hatchet Job"

25.appears_in: p. 38 in The Comics Journal, no. 118 (Dec. 1987)
notes: Letter about the review of Iger Comics Kingdom.

26.heading: Hatchet Men.
26.title: "Crime Quiz" 1 p. in Crime Does Not Pay, no. 57
26.author: [No author]
notes: Quiz questions on pyromania, ballistics, Burke and Hare, the Volstead Act, hatchet men, Vincent "Mad-Dog" Coll, Pinkertons, and narks.

27.heading: Hatchet Men.
27.title: "What Planet Are You From?"
27.author: Guisewite.
notes: Summary: Irving has downsized Cathy out of a job, and now wants her to do a performance review of his hatchet skills.

28.heading: Hatchetface.
28.title: "The Big Fight"
28.author: pencils, George Klein? ; inks, Mike Sekowsky? 10 p
notes: A villain called Hatchetface is introduced.
Data from Lou Mougin and Tony R. Rose via Grand Comics Database Project.

29.heading: Hatchets.
29.title: "But I Don't Like the Way She Plans to Get It"
29.author: Yates-Casson.
notes: Summary: Redeye seems flattered that is wife wants a lock of his hair, but she's chasing him with a hatchet.

30.heading: Hatchets.
30.title: "Cory, Is That You?"
30.author: Harold LeDoux.
notes: Summary: Mrs. Duncan finds a hatchet stuck in her front door.

31.heading: Hatchets.
31.title: "Frankly, I Expect a Call from the Police Any Minute!"
31.author: Harold LeDoux.
notes: Summary: Sam takes Mrs. Duncan home and says the police will want to question Mark, and Mark has a hatchet meeting tonight.

32.heading: Hatchets.
32.title: "I Just Met with the Mutineers and They Agreed to Bury the Hatchet"
32.author: Frank Johnson.
notes: Summary: Aarnie sees the hatchet coming and yells for Boner to duck.

33.heading: Hatchets.
33.title: "Oh, Sure! Blame Me!"
33.author: by Jim Davis.
notes: Summary: Everything in the house is chopped up, and Jon yells at Garfield, who's standing there with a hatchet.

34.heading: Hatchets.
34.title: "What's This Hatchet Doing Here?"
34.author: by Paul Nichols ; Harold LeDoux.
notes: Summary: Cory asks about the hatchet, and his wife says it belongs to Mark's friends.

113.heading: Hatfield, Charles.
113.title: "Heartbreak Soup: The Interdependence of Theme and Form"
113.author: Charles Hatfield
notes: Summary: Discusses a volume of G. and J. Hernandez' Love and Rockets.

Annotation (by Gene Kannenberg): While Heartbreak Soup is its primary focus, the article makes excellent use of film terminology as a tool; Hatfield doesn't fall into the trap of transplanting the terminology whole-scale, but rather proposes and uses some aspects, explaining just how and why they are useful in a comics context.
Includes bibliographical references.
